analysis

Class GradApproximatorMT

  • java.lang.Object
    • analysis.GradApproximatorMT
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, VecFunctionIntf

    public class GradApproximatorMT
extends java.lang.Object
implements VecFunctionIntf
    The class implements a multi-threaded version of the Richardson extrapolation method to evaluate the derivative of a differentiable function (serial version implemented in GradApproximator class of this package). Note1: unfortunately, this implementation does not have a way of checking when an nmax value in the Richardson recursion is "too much" or "too little". Note2: there is currently no way to check if the values returned are "close" to the real derivative value, or even if the derivative exists.

    Title: popt4jlib

    Description: A Parallel Meta-Heuristic Optimization Library in Java

    Copyright: Copyright (c) 2011-2020

    Company:

    Version:
    1.0
    Author:
    Ioannis T. Christou
    See Also:

    • Method Detail

      • eval

        public VectorIntf eval(VectorIntf x,
                       java.util.HashMap params)
                throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        compute the gradient of the function f passed in the constructor, at the point x using Richardson extrapolation. The params hash-table may contain the following pairs:
        • <"gradapproximator.nmax", Integer n> optional, the dimension of the Richardson extrapolation. Default is 15.
        • <"gradapproximator.numthreads", Integer nt> optional, the number threads to use when computing the gradient. Default is 1.
        Specified by:
        eval in interface VecFunctionIntf
        Parameters:
        x - VectorIntf the point at which the gradient must be evaluated.
        params - HashMap any parameters to be passed to the function f; may be null
        Returns:
        VectorIntf
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if x is null or if the algorithm fails

      • evalCoord

        public double evalCoord(VectorIntf x,
                        java.util.HashMap params,

                 throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        evaluate the partial derivative of the "coordindex"-th variable at x.
        Specified by:
